p1.heading: The Heading Tags
p1.text: HTML Headings are used to define titles or subtitles that you want to display on a webpage. HTML Headings are defined with the <h1> to <h6> tags. <h1> defines the most important heading. <h6> defines the least important heading. Headings are very important for SEO purposes. Search engines use the headings to index the structure and content of your web pages. Users often skim a page by its headings. It is important to use headings to show the document structure. p2.heading: Paragraphs
p2.text:
The p tag is used to define a paragraph. Browsers automatically add some space (margin) before and after each

element. The margins can be modified with CSS (with the margin properties). The p tag is a block-level element. The p tag has a start tag and an end tag. The p tag allows you to create multi-line text. The text inside a p element is displayed in a block element with a line break before and after the paragraph. Try the codes below to see it in action

p3.text: In the paragraph tag above we added a text know as lorem ipsum. "Lorem ipsum" is often used as a placeholder or dummy text within the content of a web page. When designing or developing a website, it is common to use temporary text to visualize the layout and overall design without having the final content available. Instead of leaving empty spaces or generic phrases like "Content goes here," web designers and developers use "Lorem ipsum" as a stand-in text. It allows them to focus on the visual aspects of the page, such as fonts, typography, spacing, and overall composition, without being distracted by the actual content.

p4.heading: The span tag
p4.text:
The tag is an inline HTML element that is used to apply styling and manipulate specific portions of text within a larger block of content. Unlike block-level elements such as
or

, the tag does not create line breaks or structural changes in the layout. Instead, it is primarily used for targeting and applying styles to individual words, phrases, or small sections of text.

p5.text: The <span> tag itself does not have any inherent styling or visual representation. Its main purpose is to provide a hook or container for CSS styles or JavaScript interactions. It is often used in conjunction with CSS classes or inline styles to customize the appearance or behavior of specific parts of the text. p7.heading: The strong tag
p7.text: This tag is used to mark the text inside it as important. The <strong> tag is often used to draw attention to a word or phrase. The <strong> tag is a phrase tag. The <strong> tag should not be used to define bold text; use the CSS font-weight property to create bold text. The <strong> tag is used to define text with strong importance. The content inside is typically displayed in bold. Try the code below to see it in action.

p8.heading: The em tag
p8.text: The <em> tag is used to define emphasized text. The content inside is typically displayed in italic. The <em> tag is a phrase tag. The <em> tag should not be used to define important text. Use the <strong> tag to define important text. Try the code below to see it in action.

p9.heading: Quotes
p9.text: The <q> tag defines a short quotation. Browsers normally insert quotation marks around the quotation. The <q> tag is used together with the cite attribute to indicate the source of the quotation. There is also a <blockquote> tag (block quotation) and it is used to define a section that is quoted from another source. Browsers usually indent <blockquote> elements. The <blockquote> element is used for longer quotes. Apart from the blockquote and the q tag there is also the <abbr> tag which is used to define an abbreviation or an acronym. The <abbr> tag is used to define an abbreviation or an acronym. We also have the <cite> tag which is used to define the title of a work. The <cite> tag defines the title of a creative work (e.g. a book, a poem, a song, a movie, a painting, a sculpture, etc.). The text in the <cite> element usually renders in italic. p10.heading: The horizontal line
p10.text: The <hr> tag defines a thematic break in an HTML page (e.g. a shift of topic). The <hr> element is used to separate content (or define a change) in an HTML page. The <hr> element is an empty element and it does not have a closing tag. The <hr> element is most often displayed as a horizontal rule in the browser, but it can also be displayed as a vertical rule or be positioned obliquely on the page.
